markdownRemark.html:
If you want to embed some code in your article, and want it to look nice, there is a simple and quick way to do it. You can use Prettify by Google. 

<p>Take this piece of Swift code for exemple:</p>
<pre style="border:1px solid black">

let myName = "Aweb"
print("Hello \(myName)")
// prints "Hello Aweb"
    </pre>

<p>
  Just embed your code in a <b><pre></b> tag, and use the relevant prettify class:
</p>
<pre class="prettyprint lang-html">

<pre class="prettyprint lang-swift">
..
let myName = "Aweb"
print("Hello \(myName)")
// prints "Hello Aweb
..
</pre>
</pre>

<p>This will render like that:</p>
<pre class="prettyprint lang-swift">

let myName = "Aweb"
print("Hello \(myName)")
// prints "Hello Aweb"
</pre>

<p>Don't forget to include Prettify at the end of the body, including or not languages plugins:</p>
<pre class="prettyprint lang-html">

<script src="https://cdn.rawgit.com/google/code-prettify/master/loader/run_prettify.js"></script>
<script src="https://cdn.rawgit.com/google/code-prettify/master/src/lang-swift.js"></script>
</pre>


<p>And lastly you can pick a custom theme. For example, I'm using a dark mode theme, called "Desert":</p>
<pre class="prettyprint lang-html">

<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdn.rawgit.com/google/code-prettify/master/styles/desert.css">
</pre>




<h3>HTML</h3>

<p>Embedding HTML is annoying because you cannot just type html code inside the <b><pre></b> tag. The raw
  html code would be interpreted as html and rendered differently that what you want. To fix that, you need to use
  an online <a href="https://mothereff.in/html-entities">HTML entity encoder/decoder</a></p>



<p>So, in order to get:</p>
<pre class="prettyprint lang-html">

<p style="color:beige">

    Embedding code in HTML

</p>
  </pre>
<p>You actually need to provide the encoded version:</p>
<pre style="border:1px solid black">

<pre class="prettyprint lang-html">
  
&#x3C;p style=&#x22;color:beige&#x22;&#x3E;
                      
    Embedding code in HTML
                      
&#x3C;/p&#x3E;
</pre>
</pre>
<h3>Conclusion</h3>
<p>So all in all, it's pretty cumbersome to write html snippets, even if you use an online encoder/decoder. For
  other languages like Swift, it remains reasonnably easy to stylise them.</p>
